alt_statements.statement: As someone who spent his career in social work, I believe university administrators have a responsibility to protect both the right to peaceful protest and the physical and emotional safety of all students, especially those who feel directly targeted or vulnerable. They should set clear, viewpoint-neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, enforce them consistently, and actively facilitate dialogue that includes Israeli, Palestinian, Jewish, Muslim, and other voices without allowing harassment or dehumanizing rhetoric.

University administrators need to enforce clear, content-neutral rules that protect free speech but draw a hard line at harassment, violence, and disruptions to classes or campus safety. Peaceful demonstrations are fine, but the moment they turn into intimidation, vandalism, or people being targeted for their religion or ethnicity—Jewish, Muslim, or anyone else—administrators should step in quickly, apply consequences, and make it clear that basic order, safety, and respect come first.

As someone who works in health care and values evidence, free inquiry, and human dignity, I think university administrators should vigorously protect peaceful protest and academic freedom around Israel/Gaza while drawing a firm, transparent line against harassment, doxxing, and direct threats to safety. They should create structured forums for dialogue—teach-ins, moderated debates, and joint events with Jewish, Muslim, Arab, and other student groups—rather than defaulting to heavy-handed policing or donor-driven pressure.

University leaders should allow peaceful demonstrations and free speech, but they must set clear rules so protests do not turn into violence, harassment, or disruption of classes. Having seen conflict and hardship in my own life, I believe they should protect every student’s safety first, treat all sides fairly, and keep politics from overshadowing the university’s main job: education and helping young people build a better future.

As someone who works in a hospital and sees the importance of safety, I think university administrators need to protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while drawing very clear lines against harassment, intimidation, or disruption of learning. They should create structured, transparent guidelines that apply equally to all groups, and facilitate dialogue that includes Jewish, Palestinian, and other affected students rather than taking a partisan stance. Administrators also have a duty of care: they should proactively provide counseling and support services for students who feel threatened or traumatized, and enforce policies consistently so campuses remain both open to dissent and fundamentally safe.

I think campus administrators need to protect both free speech and student safety, without letting things turn into harassment or intimidation. Peaceful protest should be allowed, even if it makes some people uncomfortable, but clear lines have to be drawn against blocking access to classes, threatening others, or disrupting the basic functioning of the university. They should enforce those rules consistently, no matter which side of the issue a group is on, and avoid taking overt political positions as institutions so students still feel the campus is a place for open debate, not official endorsement.

University administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak freely about Israel and Gaza, while drawing a bright, consistently enforced line at harassment, threats, and discrimination—especially antisemitism and Islamophobia. They also have a responsibility to keep campuses physically safe and open for learning, which means setting clear, content-neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, and communicating those rules transparently. As someone who values both justice and order, I’d expect administrators to facilitate difficult dialogue, not suppress it, but also to intervene quickly when activism crosses into targeted intimidation or disrupts core academic functions.

As someone who’s really into activism and plans to go to college soon, I think university administrators need to protect students’ right to protest on Israel/Gaza while also making sure everyone feels physically safe and not targeted because of their identity. They should set clear, content-neutral rules about time, place, and manner of demonstrations, and then actually listen to student voices from all sides instead of just trying to shut things down when it gets uncomfortable. Administrators should also create more structured spaces—like forums or teach-ins—where people can learn the history and hear different perspectives so protests are backed by real understanding, not just slogans.

As someone who cares deeply about both justice and community, I believe university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza while enforcing clear, consistent rules against harassment, threats, and disruption of learning. Rather than resorting quickly to police or blanket restrictions, they should facilitate dialogue, provide support for those who feel unsafe, and ensure that Palestinian, Israeli, Jewish, Muslim, and other affected students are all treated with equal dignity and concern.

I think university administrators need to protect free speech and the right to peaceful protest, but they also have a responsibility to keep campuses safe and prevent harassment or intimidation of Jewish or Muslim students. They should set and enforce clear rules: no blocking buildings, no disrupting classes, no hate speech, and serious consequences if those lines are crossed.

I think the grown‑ups in charge of universities should make sure everyone can talk and protest peacefully without being mean or violent to each other. People are really hurting on both sides, so administrators should help students listen to each other and learn the truth about what’s happening instead of just yelling. They should also keep everyone safe, no matter where they’re from or what they believe.

Universities should protect free speech, but they also have a duty to keep order and ensure that no group is threatened or harassed, whether Jewish, Arab, or anyone else.
